explanation: The model runs on data that is viewed deterministically, but is designed to be easy to use in probabilistic analysis. This applies particularly to the time series the model is run on.
explanation.3: The model is well documented and easily customisable. It is built in the Calliope framework (https://www.callio.pe/), so can be changed there.

Comments: This model used generic technology classes (baseload, peaking, and wind). These can be taken and modified to represent "real" technologies.
Additional comments: The model described here isn't a "real" power system model in terms of describing a realistic system. It is designed to be a simple "toy" model that is, above all, easy to use. The idea is that it can serve as a simple "benchmark" model to test timeseries and optimisation methodologies on. In many fields, standard benchmarks exist; notable examples are MNIST or CIFAR in Computer Vision and the Lorenz 63 system in Dynamical Systems. In contrast, test models used in power system research tend to differ per investigation, with each paper using a different (often not open-source) model. The closest thing in power system applications are the various IEEE n-bus test systems, but the code, technology characteristics and time series data are usually not standardised or provided open-source.

other spatial scope: the framework was designed to be generic and applicable to small and large systems / moreover most problems have natural boundaries that should be respected
other temporal scope: normally a year of operation, either today or some future system, was envisaged
other temporal resolution: the time step was a model parameter but either 5 minutes or 60 minutes was envisaged: the basic assumption to be fulfilled is that the system “relaxes” rapidly after each step (otherwise a continuous model is required, one based on ordinary differential equations)
other decision making: market clearing: US-style nodal pricing (aka locational marginal pricing) is supported
other heat representation: contained a square box building thermal performance module and a HVAC (heating, ventilation, and air conditioning) module

explanation: This extension aims to assess the amount of unsupplied energy and its costs, in case disturbances to the energy system occur.
explanation.2: sheddable loads: Block of equations allowing the cost-optimal amount of load shedding and its overall cost to be computed, for certain flexible demand types defined by the user.
explanation.3: The code is open source and can be extended or altered to implement new features if code complies with the requirements of linear optimisation
explanation.4: Both possible. by a function: Costs related to the flexible operation of power plants, specifically: increased specific fuel consumption at lower load, wear and tear costs associated to the number of ramp-up and ramp-down cycles and costs for refurbishing existing units.
explanation.5: Equations that model the ramping constraints of conventional generators. With large penetrations of variable renewables, the ramping demand in the system is significantly increased. The ability to constrain the ramping capabilities of generators in the system allows for a more accurate representation of the system dynamics and associated costs.
